thread.title: Rio Arriba County employee arrested for 2nd DWI
thread.title_full: Rio Arriba County employee arrested for 2nd DWI | Albuquerque Journal News

author: Edmundo Carrillo / Journal Staff Writer
title: Rio Arriba County employee arrested for 2nd DWI
text:
SANTA FE — A Rio Arriba County employee was arrested for his second DWI last week.
Carlos Trujillo
According to a Santa Fe County Sheriff’s Office DWI offense report, Carlos Trujillo, Rio Arriba’s public information officer, was arrested and booked into the Santa Fe County jail last Thursday after police say he was recklessly driving and passed out behind the wheel.
A human resources employee with the county confirmed that Trujillo is the county’s public information officer Wednesday. Neither County Manager Tomas Campos or Deputy County Manager David Trujillo could be reached for comment on Carlos Trujillo’s employment status o rhiringCarlos Trujillo first pled no contest to DWI in 2010.
A deputy arrived at a residence on Cowboy Lane in the Arroyo Seco area of northern Santa Fe County in response to a report of a reckless driver. The deputy located and approached Trujillo, 33, who was still in the driver’s seat with the engine running. Trujillo told the deputy he was waiting for a ride because he didn’t have a driver’s license and said he didn’t know who lived at the residence. The deputy noted that Trujillo was having trouble speaking and had fresh injection marks on his arms. Trujillo admitted to injecting heroin earlier that day and taking Xanax, typically used to treat panic and anxiety disorders.
Medics were called to the scene after field sobriety tests were conducted because Trujillo was drifting in and out of consciousness and they transported him to the Christus St. Vincent Regional Medical Center in Santa Fe for low oxygen levels. His 2008 Mercedes was seized in accordance with county ordinance.
Trujillo also had a driving with a revoked license charge dropped without prejudice in Santa Fe County Magistrate Court in 2013. He was released on the latest charge with a $2,500 surety bond.
